Package squidpony.squidmath

Class LapRNG

java.lang.Object
squidpony.squidmath.LapRNG
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, RandomnessSource
@Beta
public class LapRNG
extends Object
implements RandomnessSource, Serializable
Like FlapRNG, this sacrifices quality for speed, but it uses 64-bit math and as such has a larger period (FlapRNG will repeat the cycle of random numbers it produces after about 8 billion numbers, while this will only repeat after many more, probably 2 to the 65). As such, LapRNG is like FlapRNG but can generate for a longer period of time (more laps) without repeating, and in some cases (mainly generating 64-bit values) at even higher speed. It is currently the fastest RandomnessSource in this library at generating 64-bit longs, which is most of what RNG uses, and is second-fastest at generating 32-bit ints, with FlapRNG just slightly faster at that. While the period must be at least 2 to the 64, it is likely that it is actually 2 to the 65. This is one of three RandomnessSources recommended for frequent use, but only if speed is the only consideration; the quality of the numbers this produces is very bad (though it appears random to even a trained human eye, a computer could detect patterns).
Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/25/2017.
See Also:
FlapRNG is similar to LapRNG but is implemented using int math; LapRNG should usually be preferred, Serialized Form

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    LapRNG()
    Constructs a LapRNG with a random internal state, using Math.random() three times to get enough bits and passing responsibility off to LapRNG(int, int, int).
    LapRNG​(int seed)
    Given one int for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant.
    LapRNG​(int seed0, int seed1)
    This constructor takes ints for seeds, but internally LapRNG uses longs, so it multiplies each input by a large constant and adds another to get the state it actually will start with.
    LapRNG​(int seed0, int seed1, int seed2)
    This constructor takes 3 ints for seeds, but internally LapRNG uses 2 longs (one, state0, only considers its upper 48 bits significant and has closely correlated results if inputs don't differ on significant bits).
    LapRNG​(long seed)
    Given one long for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant.
    LapRNG​(long seed0, long seed1)
    The only constructor that does not modify its seeds in some way; you should ensure seed0 is large enough (at least 25 bits should be needed to represent it, so greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433).
    LapRNG​(CharSequence seed)
    This constructor gets three differently-calculated 32-bit hash codes from the given String or other CharSequence and gives them to the constructor that takes three ints, LapRNG(int, int, int).

  • Constructor Details

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG()
      Constructs a LapRNG with a random internal state, using Math.random() three times to get enough bits and passing responsibility off to LapRNG(int, int, int).

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(long seed)
      Given one long for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
      Parameters:
      seed - any long; will not be used verbatim for either internal state

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(int seed)
      Given one int for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
      Parameters:
      seed - any int; will not be used verbatim for either internal state

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(long seed0, long seed1)
      The only constructor that does not modify its seeds in some way; you should ensure seed0 is large enough (at least 25 bits should be needed to represent it, so greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433). If seed0 is too small, then this will appear highly repetitive for many cycles before changing its output pattern.
      Parameters:
      seed0 - a long that should be greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433, preferably by a large amount
      seed1 - any long

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(int seed0, int seed1)
      This constructor takes ints for seeds, but internally LapRNG uses longs, so it multiplies each input by a large constant and adds another to get the state it actually will start with. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
      Parameters:
      seed0 - any int, will not be used verbatim
      seed1 - any int, will not be used verbatim

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(int seed0, int seed1, int seed2)
      This constructor takes 3 ints for seeds, but internally LapRNG uses 2 longs (one, state0, only considers its upper 48 bits significant and has closely correlated results if inputs don't differ on significant bits). To ensure the state works fairly well, this uses seed0 to affect the upper 48 bits of state0 (this also uses the product of seed1 and seed2), while employing all 3 seed parameters again to set state1 (but these can affect all 64 bits of state1). Note that only 96 bits of parameter are supplied here to set 128 bits of state, which is all right in this case because LapRNG only has a period of 2 to the 65. Anything more than 65 bits of state isn't strictly necessary, though giving more should allow different, non-overlapping sequences to be produced. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
      Parameters:
      seed0 - any int, will not be used verbatim; should probably not be 0
      seed1 - any int, will not be used verbatim; should probably not be 0
      seed2 - any int, will not be used verbatim; should probably not be 0

    • LapRNG

      public LapRNG​(CharSequence seed)
      This constructor gets three differently-calculated 32-bit hash codes from the given String or other CharSequence and gives them to the constructor that takes three ints, LapRNG(int, int, int). You can pass a null seed and this will still work.
      Parameters:
      seed - any CharSequence, such as a String

  • Method Details

    • next

      public final int next​(int bits)
      Using this method, any algorithm that might use the built-in Java Random can interface with this randomness source.
      Specified by:
      next in interface RandomnessSource
      Parameters:
      bits - the number of bits to be returned
      Returns:
      the integer containing the appropriate number of bits

    • nextInt

      public final int nextInt()
      Gets a pseudo-random int, which can be positive or negative but is likely to be drawn from less possible options than the full range of Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE. Very fast, though.
      Returns:
      a pseudo-random 32-bit int

    • nextLong

      public final long nextLong()
      Using this method, any algorithm that needs to efficiently generate more than 32 bits of random data can interface with this randomness source. This implementation is the primary one, and nextInt() and next(int) just use some portion of the bits this produces. It should be very, very fast on most desktops, with lower speed relative to its closest competitor (FlapRNG) on 32-bit operating systems or 32-bit JREs or JDKs, and possibly lower speed on mobile devices as well, but at the time of writing LapRNG is the fastest source SquidLib has of pseudo-random long values.

      Pseudo-random results may be between between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).

      Specified by:
      nextLong in interface RandomnessSource
      Returns:
      a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive)

    • copy

      public LapRNG copy()
      Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just need to copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
      Specified by:
      copy in interface RandomnessSource
      Returns:
      a copy of this RandomnessSource

    • getState0

      public long getState0()
      Gets the linearly-changing part of the state.
      Returns:
      one of the two parts of the state as a long

    • setState0

      public void setState0​(long state0)
      Sets the linearly-changing part of the state; if the parameter is too small, the generator will behave poorly. At minimum, the parameter should have significant bits beyond the 24th bit (greater than 33554432 for positive longs), and should ideally be larger than can be represented in a 32-bit int.
      Parameters:
      state0 - a large-enough long, either greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433, preferably greatly so

    • getState1

      public long getState1()
      Gets the irregularly-changing part of the state.
      Returns:
      one of the two parts of the state as a long

    • setState1

      public void setState1​(long state1)
      Sets the irregularly-changing part of the state; just about any long can be passed as a reasonable value here.
      Parameters:
      state1 - any long
